name: tomato
comment: black walnuts inhibit tomato growth,[12] in fact they are negative allelopathic to all other nightshade plants (chili pepper, potato, tobacco, petunia) as well, because it produces a chemical called juglone. dill attracts tomato hornworm. growing tomatoes with basil does not appear to enhance tomato flavour but studies have shown that growing them around 10 inches apart can increase the yield of tomatoes by about 20%.[81] one study shows that growing chili peppers near tomatoes in greenhouses increases tomato whitefly on the tomatoes.[61] cucumbers and squash can be used as living mulch, or green mulch, around tomato plants. the large leaves of these vining plants can help with soil moisture retention.[84]

name: southernwood
comment: controls cabbage moths and malaria mosquitoes.

name: yarrow
comment: may increase the essential oil production of some herbs. also improves soil quality, use the leaves to enrich compost, or as mulch. because it attracts syrphidae it reduces aphids through predation.[69]

name: spinach
comment: the peas and beans provide natural shade for the spinach. see cauliflower notes regarding mutualism with spinach.[*citation needed*]

name: summer savory
comment: also delays germination of certain foul herbs

name: onion
comment: see alliums entry for more info

name: geranium
comment: a trap crop, attracting pests away from roses and grape vines, distracts beet leafhoppers, carrier of the curly top virus, keep away from solanaceous plants like eggplant, and tobacco

name: beet
comment: good for adding minerals to the soil through composting leaves which have up to 25% magnesium. runner or pole beans and beets stunt each other's growth.

name: californian poppy
comment: because they attract syrphidae they help reduce aphids through predation. [69]

name: dill
comment: one of the few plants said to grow with fennel.[*citation needed*] see fennel for info about intercropping.

name: peanut
comment: peanuts encourage growth of corn and squash[92]

name: wormwood
comment: wormwood should be used with caution around most vegetables since it does contain toxins.[12]

name: squash
comment: radishes can be used as a trap crop against flea beetles, cucurbita can be used in the three sisters technique. marigolds[30] and nasturtiums repel squash bugs.[12][66] marigolds repel cucumber beetles.[30]

name: lavender
scientific_name: Lavandula angustifolia, L. dentata, L. stoechas

name: anise
comment: not to be confused with star anise which is an entirely different species.

name: pansy
comment: a good and nice-smelling flower that really attracts ants. it is like the viola plant, but has two or three colors in flowers. helps alliums and onions, which repels the white butterfly.

name: crownvetch
comment: Crownvetch is toxic to horses and other non-ruminants because of the presence of nitroglycosides.

name: potato
comment: horseradish increases the disease resistance of potatoes. it repels the potato bug.[22] garlic was shown to be more effective than fungicides on late potato blight.[77] peas were shown to reduce the density of colorado potato beetles.[7]

name: soybean
comment: a mixture of corn, mungbean, and sunflower was found to rid soybeans of aphids.[51] snap beans act as a trap crop for mexican bean beetles in soybeans.[*citation needed*]

name: pole bean
comment: the stalk of the corn provides a pole for the beans to grow on, which then gives nitrogen to the soil of the corn.[20][*circular reference*] as for the radishes, see the entry for "legumes" for more info

name: lily
comment: Not all lilies are toxic, and some are more toxic to animals, especially cats, than to humans.

name: tarragon
comment: its scent is disliked by most pests, and this plant is also thought to have nurse plant properties, enhancing the growth and flavor of crops grown with it.

name: bush bean
comment: lettuce, potato, tomato, other legumes, crucifers, or cucurbits *increase* sclerotinia in the soil and should be avoided before and after snap beans. [18] see the entry for "legumes" for more info

name: foxglove
comment: Foxglove has medicinal uses but is also very toxic to humans and other animals, and consumption can even lead to death.

name: zinnia
comment: attracts hummingbirds that eat whiteflies, attracts pollinators

name: petunia
comment: is a trap crop almost identical to geraniums in function

name: jimson weed
comment: It is an aggressive invasive weed in temperate climates across the world.[2] D. stramonium has frequently been employed in traditional medicine to treat a variety of ailments. It has also been used as a hallucinogen (of the anticholinergic/antimuscarinic, deliriant type), taken entheogenically to cause intense, sacred or occult visions.[2][7] It is unlikely ever to become a major drug of abuse owing to effects upon both mind and body frequently perceived as being highly unpleasant, giving rise to a state of profound and long-lasting disorientation or delirium (anticholinergic syndrome) with a potentially fatal outcome. It contains tropane alkaloids which are responsible for the psychoactive effects, and may be severely toxic.

name: marigold
scientific_name: Tagetes patula, T. erecta, T. minuta
comment: marigolds are a wonder-drug of the companion plant world, invoking the saying "plant them everywhere in your garden". french marigolds (t. patula) produce a pesticidal chemical from their roots, so strong it lasts years after they are gone. mexican marigolds (t. erecta) do the same, but are so strong they will inhibit the growth of some more tender herbs. stinking roger (t. minuta) has also been found effective against certain perennial weeds.[97] same with lupin, planting nearby roses causes them to grow vigorously.

name: catnip
comment: Some members of this group are known as catnip or catmint because of their effect on house cats – the nepetalactone contained in some Nepeta species binds to the olfactory receptors of cats, typically resulting in temporary euphoria.

name: daffodil
comment: All Narcissus species contain the alkaloid poison lycorine, mostly in the bulb but also in the leaves.

name: parsnip
comment: the flowers of the parsnip plant left to seed will attract a variety of predatory insects to the garden, they are particularly helpful when left under fruit trees, the predators attacking codling moth and light brown apple moth. the root also contains myristricin, which is toxic to fruit flies, house flies, red spider mite, pea aphids, a simple blender made extraction of three blended parsnips roots to one litre of water through a food processor (not one for preparing food) and left overnight, strained and use within a few days.

name: lettuce
comment: mints (including hyssop, sage, and various "balms") repel slugs, a bane of lettuce and cabbages.[*citation needed*] broccoli when intercropped with lettuce was shown to be more profitable than either crop alone.[33]

name: brassica
comment: *brassicas are a family of plants which includes broccoli, brussels sprouts, cabbage, cauliflower, chinese cabbage, kohlrabi, radish, and turnip.* thyme, nasturtiums, and onion showed good resistance to cabbage worm, weevil and cabbage looper.[30]

name: chamomile
comment: growing near herbs will increase their oil production.

name: swan plant
comment: attracts the monarch butterfly during spring and summer. basil repels pests that attracts by the swan plant like aphids.

name: cucumber
comment: sow 2 or 3 radish seeds in with cucumbers to repel cucumber beetles.[12] one study showed a 75% reduction in cucumber beetles with the concurrent seeding of amaranth.[59] various sprays from lettuce, asparagus, malabar spinach, and celery were found to reduce whiteflies.[50] see cucurbits entry for more info

name: cauliflower
comment: one row of spinach alternating at 60 cm from each row of cauliflower proved mutually beneficial.[*citation needed*] see brassicas for more info. see peas regarding their mutualism with cauliflower.

name: spearmint
comment: controls ants and aphids, has same general companion properties as other mints.

name: pumpkin
comment: radishes can be used as a trap crop against flea beetles, cucurbita can be used in the three sisters technique. nasturtiums repel squash bugs.[12]

name: atriplex
comment: they are able to grow in areas affected by soil salination

name: alyssum
comment: because they attract syrphidae they help reduce aphids through predation. [69]

name: cabbage
comment: see brassicas entry for more info. if using clover as an intercrop it should be sown after cabbage transplant so as not to affect crop yield. nasturtiums repel cabbage moths[22]

name: eggplant
comment: marigolds will deter nematodes.

name: borage
comment: predict a square metre for its adult size. borage is a good companion for a wide variety of plants.[17]

name: strawberry
comment: thyme planted and/or placed next to each other help grow more strawberries quickly.

name: sweet pea
comment: an annual climbing plant, which is like the edible pea. makes a good decoration in your garden or fence.

name: leek
comment: see alliums entry for more info

name: sunflower
comment: was grown as a companion for corn (maize) before modern europeans arrived in the americas, supposedly increases their production, ants herd aphids onto sunflowers, keeping them off neighboring plants. works as a trap plant for thrips keeping them off of bell peppers.[74] planting near swan plants help sunflowers grow rapidly.

name: mustard
comment: see brassicas entry for more info. mustard acts as a trap crop in broccoli.[*citation needed*]

name: chive
comment: same companion traits as all alliums (onions, garlic, shallots, leeks, etc.)said to prevent apple scab after 3 years planting at base of apple trees

name: turnip
comment: turnips act as a trap crop for broccoli.[35] see peas regarding their mutualism with turnips.

name: rosemary
comment: deters cabbage flies, repels many bean parasites

name: hyssop
comment: stimulates growth of grapes.

name: thyme
comment: because it attracts syrphidae it reduces aphids through predation.[69]

name: baby's breath
comment: because they attract syrphidae they help reduce aphids through predation. [69]

name: oregano
comment: provides ground cover and much-needed humidity for pepper plants if allowed to spread among them. because it attracts syrphidae, it reduces aphids through predation.[69]

name: corn
comment: provides beans with a trellis, is protected from predators and dryness by cucurbits, in the three sisters technique

name: nasturtium
comment: trap crops for aphids, is among the best at attracting predatory insects, deters many pests of cucurbits

name: sweet potato
comment: okra and sweet potato are mutually beneficial when planted simultaneously.

name: fava bean
comment: see the entry for "legumes" for more info

name: cilantro
comment: attracts hoverflies which may in turn reduce pest populations in cabbages. [41]

name: Sericea lespedeza
comment: It is native to Asia and eastern Australia[3] and it is present elsewhere as an introduced species and sometimes an invasive plant.

name: lemon grass
comment: has been shown to reduce cutworms in eggplant in laboratory trials but needs field testing

name: okra
comment: okra and sweet potato are mutually beneficial when planted simultaneously.

name: alfalfa
comment: used by farmers to reduce cotton pests, a good crop to improve soil; fixes nitrogen like beans do. also breaks up hardpan and other tough soil. alfalfa has demonstrated some allelopathic effects to tomato seedlings[85]

name: phacelia
comment: this plant attracts hoverflies and is good around plants which are prone to aphids.[98]

name: lupin
comment: this wildflower is a legume, hosting bacteria that fixes nitrogen in the soil, fertilizing it for neighboring plants. same with marigold, planting nearby roses causes them to grow vigorously.

name: peppermint
comment: repels cabbage flies, has same general companion properties as other mints

name: lovage
comment: is thought to improve the health of almost all plants, like borage and geraniums, is considered a "magic bullet" of companion planting

name: walnut
comment: black walnut is harmful to the growth of all nightshade plants, including *datura* or jimson weed, eggplant, mandrake, deadly nightshade or belladonna, capsicum (paprika, chile pepper), potato, tomato, and petunia.

name: parsley
comment: sacrificially attracts insects that feed on tomatoes

name: kohlrabi
comment: see brassicas entry for more info

name: pepper
comment: pepper plants like high humidity, which can be helped along by planting with some kind of dense-leaf or ground-cover companion, like marjoram and basil; they also need direct sunlight, but their fruit can be harmed by it...pepper plants grown together, or with tomatoes, can shelter the fruit from sunlight, and raises the humidity level. sunflowers, when in bloom at the right time, sheltered beneficial insects which lowered thrips populations.[73]

name: radish
comment: radishes can be used as a trap crop against flea beetles. radishes grown with lettuce taste better.[12]

name: flax
comment: flax contains tannin and linseed oils which may offend the colorado potato bug[92]

name: tansy
comment: toxic to people and many animals, don't plant it where livestock browse. is reputed to generally repel insects (except for nectar-eating types).

name: fennel
comment: Fennel is not friendly and is allelopathic to most garden plants, inhibiting growth or causing them to bolt. It actually kills many plants. Dill is the only thing you can plant with fennel. Other than that plant it by itself. On a positive note the foliage and flowers attract beneficials such as ladybugs, syrphid flies, tachninid flies, beneficial parasitoid wasps and hoverflies Fennel is a good flea repellent. An old saying says to "plant fennel near your kennel" to deter fleas. Dried fennel leaves provide additional flea repelling insurance when put inside the dog house or kennel.

name: garlic
comment: see alliums entry for more info. peas and garlic when planted closely together suppress each other's growth; however the profit over land area used is higher.[47] tarragon makes garlic grow rapidly.

name: basil
comment: is said to make tomatoes taste better, chamomile and anise are supposed to increase the essential oils in many herbs like basil

name: blueberry
comment: pine and oak trees create the acidic soil blueberries need. strawberries and dewberries create healthy ground cover, clover fixes nitrogen for the blueberries' high needs, yarrow and bay laurel repel unhealthy insects. each of the herbal companions listed also like the acidic soil the blueberry plant needs.

name: pea
comment: peas when intercropped with turnips, cauliflower, or garlic showed mutual suppression of growth however their profit per land area used was increased. [47]

name: chervil
comment: loves shade, fortunately it grows well with shade-tolerant food plants; will make radishes grown near it taste spicier

name: celery
comment: aster flowers, can transmit the aster yellows disease

name: comfrey
comment: Comfrey contains mixed phytochemicals in varying amounts, including allantoin, mucilage, saponins, tannins, pyrrolizidine alkaloids, and inulin, among others.[6] Pyrrolizidine alkaloids are responsible for comfreys production of hepatotoxicity.[7]Liver toxicity is associated with consuming this plant or its extracts.[6] In modern herbalism, comfrey is most commonly used topically.[6][8][9]

name: broccoli
comment: broccoli as a main crop intercropped with lettuce was shown to be more profitable than either crop alone.[33] turnip acts as a trap crop.[35] see brassicas entry for more info

name: carrot
comment: tomatoes grow better with carrots, but may stunt the carrots' growth. beans provide the nitrogen carrots need more than some other vegetables. aromatic companion plants repel carrot fly. sage, rosemary, and radishes are recommended by *some* as companion plants, but listed by others as incompatible. alliums inter-planted with carrots confuse onion and carrot flies. for the beneficial insect-attracting properties of carrots to work, they need to be allowed to flower; otherwise, use the wild carrot, queen anne's lace, for the same effect. flax produces an oil that may protect root vegetables like carrots from some pests.

name: apricot
comment: a fungus that peppers are prone to can infect apricot trees causing a lot of harm.
